crop-plan.about-dividing-description: Utilizing the inherent versatility of a field, it is possible to implement multiple cycles of sowing and harvesting within the same boundaries throughout the growing season
crop-plan.about-dividing-description-long: Utilizing the inherent versatility of a field, it is possible to implement multiple cycles of sowing and harvesting within the same boundaries throughout the growing season. Leveraging this capability, farmers can strategically devise crop plans for distinct sections of their fields and seamlessly execute those plans while maintaining the integrity of the field boundaries.

analysis.short-ndv-text: On this page, you can see the plant density distribution on the health map for your field. On top of the image, you will see the average NDVI value indicating the plant density of your field. This value ranges from 0 to 1, approaching 1 as your plants develop and 0 towards harvest.
analysis.empty-content: Talk to our sales team to access up-to-date satellite imagery.
analysis.get-in-touch: You don’t have any satellite images. Get in touch with our team for help.
analysis.contact-satellite-imagery: Our team will reach out to you in approximately 12 hours about your interest in satellite imagery
analysis.health-map-text:
"The Health map indicates a trend in the field based on the average NDVI value. Rather than associating a set meaning to colors, you must analyze the map according to the deviations from the average values and colors with the growth stages of crops. Any variation from the prominent color must be inspected.

From Sprouting to Budding: At this stage, crops are growing and getting greener, but this doesn't necessarily equate to a green health map. For example, green areas might indicate weed growth if the prominent color is yellow. Dark green might mean that some spots are growing faster, requiring a soil analysis to understand which elements are lacking in the other parts of the field.

From Flowering to Harvest: Usually, at this stage, crops change colors due to flowering, fruiting, and ripening. For example, if the prominent color is yellow, green areas might indicate a developmental problem where the flowers are not blooming."
analysis.atmospheric-obstacles: Regions with no date due to the atmospheric obstacles such as cloud, cloud shadow and haze.
analysis.for-field-natural: For a field with a natural growth rate, the changes in the colors of the map follow a bell curve, climbing up to dark green until flowering and turning down to browner hues towards harvest.
analysis.observing-inconsistent: If you are observing inconsistent colors with the expected phenological behavior of the plant, it indicates that there may be agricultural problems in that region, during these dates.
